Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Effects of Extracellular Matrix Alignment on Cellular Mechanotransduction in 3D Architectures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cells in living organisms reside in a meshwork of protein fibers and other molecules, termed the extracellular matrix, which provides both structural support and chemical inputs that are critical to the functioning of the cells. The structural properties of the extracellular matrix are largely determined by how these protein fibers are aligned and organized, and changes in these structures and are associated with the progression of many human diseases, but in ways that in many cases are still not well understood. This award supports fundamental research that will provide needed insights into how the organization and resulting mechanical properties of the extracellular matrix influence and control both the normal and pathological behavior of cells. This research is relevant to ongoing efforts to develop methods to speed wound healing, and to engineer artificial tissues to repair damaged organs, and so the results from this work will have broad impact and provide critical resources to the biomedical community. This collaborative research program involves techniques and insights drawn from several fields, including bioengineering, physics, microfabrication, and cell biology, and provides interdisciplinary training needed to prepare the next generation of scientists and engineers.

The adhesion of cells to the extracellular matrix plays a major role in many critical cellular functions important to embryonic development, adult tissue homeostasis, and disease pathogenesis, including cell survival, migration, proliferation, and differentiation. Yet, there have been few systems that allow control and therefore study the specific effects of fibrillar extracellular matrix architecture on cell function. This project use engineered microtissues to address the key hypothesis that alterations in the alignment of matrix, contractile activity of resident cells, geometry of boundary constraints, and external mechanical forces are highly coupled in a mechanotransduction machinery that will drive changes in cellular phenotype. These studies will determine how these factors regulate the transition of fibroblasts to an activated, fibrotic phenotype that is critical in wound healing as well as chronic fibrosis and scarring, but will apply more broadly to many cell types that response to mechanoadhesive cues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES

Intellectual Merit:

The interactions with and adhesion of cells to matrix of proteins and other structures that surround them (the extracellular matrix or ECM) play a major role in many critical cellular functions important to embryonic development, the functioning of adult tissue, and the development of disease, including cell survival, migration, proliferation, and differentiation. Cell adhesion involves the coordination between adhesive and mechanical processes, including receptor-mediated binding, cell spreading and extension along the matrix, and cell-generated forces at the cell-matrix interface. As a result, cell-matrix interactions are regulated by not only the chemical composition of the ECM, but also its physical organization and mechanics.

This collaborative project between researchers at Johns Hopkins University and Boston University drew on tools and concepts from microfabrication, magnetic devices, tissue engineering, and cell biology to study how the architecture of collagen matrices impact the mechanical properties of tissue and how cells function within a three-dimensional tissue setting.  Devices were developed jointly by the research team that contained arrays of microtissues, each approximately 1 mm in size, and composed of cells and the fibrous protein collagen, one of the principal components of the ECM.  The microtissues were formed in small wells that contained a set of flexible pillars. The contractile forces of the cells caused the collagen/cell composites to contract and form elastic tissue structures suspended between the pillars, like a rubber band stretched between two fingers, or a trampoline stretched on a metal frame. The bending of the pillars provides a readout of the cellular forces in the tissues, and magnetic material on some of the pillars allows the tissues to be stretched to measure their mechanical response. Elongated tissues had high degrees of alignment of the collagen fibers, and more symmetric structures had more nearly isotropic structure.

This system was used to carry out studies in two main areas: the role of tissue structure on the dynamics of wound healing in experiments carried out mainly at Boston University, and the influence of tissue geometry and microstructure on tissue mechanical properties in experiments carried out mainly at Johns Hopkins. Key findings from the wound healing studies, which used a diamond-tipped microknife to cut holes into the microtissue, after which the cells spontaneously closed and healed the wound (See Fig. 1), were that there are dramatically different rates and modes of wound closing, depending on the microtissue alignment, with aligned tissues healing much more slowly than non-aligned tissues. The curvature of the wound appears to be critical in determining the rate at which the cells can deposit new matrix to close the wound.  These results shed new light on how cells function in environments with different local geometries and may have implications for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.

The results of the research have been reported through publications in scientific journals and presentations at conferences.

 

Broader Impacts:

Dissemination of the methods for use of these new devices and associated approaches to a broader research community will enable a broad range of new studies in cell-matrix interactions and tissue mechanics beyond just the research groups directly involved, and will provide input to the development of a rational foundation for designing ways to control cell function. This project has contributed to the development of the nation?s scientific and technical workforce by providing advanced interdisciplinary research training to a postdoctoral fellow and several graduate students that has prepared them for careers in academia and industry. The work described above will form a major component one of the student?s Ph.D. dissertation.  An undergraduate and a high school student participated in the project through research internships, and their experiences have catalyzed their further study of science and engineering.
